CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 27, 1955, pg. 15, reads: "Washington Playground - This playground, at one time the home field of the Pittsburgh Crawford, will have new buildings erected on it, but the colorful sports figures who played there will live in memories for years to come. Last year the Washington Park Oldtimers had a reunion and the roster showed that quite a few members of the group had distinguished themselves in various fields of endeavor. - All Harris Photos."  Portions of accompanying article by George Barbour on p. 3, read: "Word on Lower Hill: 'Say Goodbye Next Spring' Residents, Old Landmarks Must Bow to Progress - For every gain there's a loss and that's the gist of the story on the Lower Hill District redevelopment project.  Besides the many Third Ward homes, there also are other endeared friends of the residents, and the city in general.  They are the various institutions which in past have responded wholeheartedly to the needs of the scores of tenants in the area.  There's no cause for alarm, but starting next spring, 'goodbyes' will be in order for the historic landmarks and places many have known as 'home.'  Many months or even years may pass before the headache balls topple the last surviving landmark into a heap of masonry and twisted steel, but the machinery of Pittsburgh progress - the Urban Redevelopment Authority - is already being lubricated to swing into action." ... "The official word is that by next spring, people and institutions will have to leave some of the sectors wile others may remain for as long as four years." ... "The Lower Hill project, which is earmarked for a 1958 completion date will feature the Crosstown Boulevard, a civic arena, luxury-type apartments, and business establishments..."
TitMainTitle: Playing field of Washington Park seen from above, with view of Downtown in background, Hill District
